Net worth is a measure of your financial health. It\'s calculated by subtracting your total liabilities (what you owe) from your total assets (what you own).

Assets include:
- Liquid assets (cash, chequing accounts, savings accounts)
- Investment assets (stocks, bonds, mutual funds, GICs, real estate investments)
- Retirement assets (RRSPs, TFSAs, employer pension plans, LIRAs)
- Personal assets (home, vehicle, valuables, collectibles)

Liabilities include:
- Short-term debts (credit cards, lines of credit, outstanding bills)
- Long-term debts (mortgages, student loans, vehicle loans)

For example, if you have %1$s500,000 in assets and %1$s200,000 in liabilities, your net worth is %1$s300,000.

A positive net worth means you own more than you owe, which is a sign of financial stability. Tracking your net worth over time helps you measure your financial progress and make informed decisions about your money.

A mortgage is a loan used to purchase property. The property itself serves as collateral for the loan, meaning the lender can take possession if you fail to make payments.

How it works: When you take out a mortgage, you borrow money to buy a property and repay it over a set period (usually 25-30 years) through monthly payments. Each payment includes:
- Principal: The amount borrowed
- Interest: The cost of borrowing
- Property Tax: Municipal property taxes divided into monthly payments
- Home Insurance: Property insurance
- CMHC Insurance: Required when down payment is less than 20%%

For example, if you buy a home for %1$s500,000 with a %1$s100,000 down payment, you\'ll borrow %1$s400,000. At a 4%% interest rate over 25 years, your monthly payment (including taxes and insurance) will be approximately %1$s2,400.

A tax calculator helps you estimate your combined federal and provincial income tax liability based on your income, filing status, and deductions. This helps you plan your finances and avoid surprises at tax time.

How it works: Enter your annual income, province of residence, and deductions. The calculator estimates your tax liability using federal and provincial tax brackets and shows your effective tax rate.

For example, if you earn %1$s75,000 annually in Ontario with standard deductions, your combined federal and provincial tax would be approximately %1$s15,000.
